hero.description: Passionate AI Developer and Data Analyst with expertise in building intelligent systems, analyzing complex datasets, and delivering high-quality software solutions. Specialized in machine learning, full-stack development, and quality assurance with a proven track record of successful projects and certifications.

about.title: About Me
about.summary1: I'm a passionate and detail-oriented Computer Science student at FEU Institute of Technology, specializing in AI development, data analysis, and quality assurance. With over 4 years of combined experience in software development and customer service, I've successfully delivered 15+ projects ranging from AI-powered chatbots to data analytics systems.
about.summary2: My expertise spans across full-stack development, machine learning, and quality assurance. I've worked with cutting-edge technologies like GPT-4, LangChain, and various ML frameworks to build intelligent solutions that solve real-world problems. My strong foundation in testing and automation ensures that every project I work on meets the highest quality standards.
about.summary3: Beyond technical skills, I bring excellent communication abilities honed through 2 years of customer service experience, where I maintained HIPAA and financial compliance standards. I thrive in collaborative environments and have successfully led and participated in multiple team projects, including organizing major tech events like CS Expo 2024.

post1.title: How I Started Learning Python and Fell in Love with Programming
post1.excerpt: Looking back at my journey, Python was the language that really opened my eyes to what programming could do. It all started when I was trying to automate some repetitive tasks...
post1.content:
Looking back at my journey, Python was the language that really opened my eyes to what programming could do. It all started when I was trying to automate some repetitive tasks in my daily work. I remember spending hours doing the same thing over and over, and I thought there had to be a better way. That's when I discovered Python. The syntax was so clean and readable that even as a beginner, I could understand what the code was doing. I spent my first week just reading through Python tutorials online, and honestly, I was amazed at how intuitive it felt compared to other languages I'd tried before.

What really got me hooked was when I wrote my first script that saved me hours of work. The feeling of solving a problem with code was incredible - like I had discovered a superpower. From there, I started exploring more - data structures, object-oriented programming, and eventually, machine learning. I remember staying up until 3 AM one night just because I couldn't stop working on a script that was processing data. My friends thought I was crazy, but I was having so much fun that I didn't even notice the time passing.

Now, Python is my go-to language for almost everything - from building APIs to training ML models. The community is amazing, and there's always something new to learn. I've built so many projects with it, and each one teaches me something different. If you're just starting out, my advice is to start with small projects and build from there. Don't try to learn everything at once - focus on one thing, master it, then move to the next. Trust me, the journey is worth it.

post2.title: My First Week as an AI Developer Intern: What I Learned
post2.excerpt: Starting my internship at FEU Institute of Technology was both exciting and nerve-wracking. I had the theoretical knowledge, but putting it into practice was a whole different story...
post2.content:
Starting my internship at FEU Institute of Technology was both exciting and nerve-wracking. I had the theoretical knowledge from school, but putting it into practice was a whole different story. On my first day, I was assigned to work on the AI chatbot project. I thought I knew what I was doing, but reality hit me hard. The codebase was massive - thousands of lines of code that I'd never seen before. Understanding how everything connected was overwhelming at first, and I spent the entire first day just trying to figure out where to even start.

What helped me the most was asking questions. I learned that there's no shame in not knowing something, and my mentors were actually really patient and always willing to explain things. I also discovered the importance of reading documentation thoroughly - it saves so much time in the long run. By the third day, I had a better grasp of the project structure, and I started feeling more confident. I even found a small bug in the codebase that nobody had noticed before, which made me feel like I was actually contributing.

By the end of the first week, I had written my first test cases and fixed a few bugs. The satisfaction of seeing my code work in production was indescribable. I realized that internships aren't just about what you know - they're about how fast you can learn and adapt. One thing I'll always remember from that week: always test your code before pushing. I learned that the hard way when I broke something on my second day. But hey, that's how you learn, right? The team was understanding, and it became a running joke that I was the 'bug finder' because I kept discovering issues.

post3.title: Building TALA: The Challenges and Wins of My Capstone Project
post3.excerpt: TALA was more than just a school project for me - it was a chance to build something real that people could actually use. But man, was it challenging...
post3.content:
TALA was more than just a school project for me - it was a chance to build something real that people could actually use. But man, was it challenging. The idea came from my own frustration with calendar apps. They never seemed to understand what I really wanted, and I kept missing important deadlines because the reminders weren't smart enough. So I thought, why not build one that uses AI to actually help? I pitched the idea to my professor, and surprisingly, he loved it. That's when I knew I was onto something.

The biggest challenge was getting the AI scheduling algorithm right. I spent weeks tweaking it, testing different approaches, and sometimes it felt like I was going in circles. There were days when I wanted to give up - I remember one particular night where I stayed up until 5 AM trying to fix a bug that was causing the calendar to double-book events. I was so frustrated that I almost deleted everything and started over. But I didn't, and the next morning, with fresh eyes, I found the issue in less than 10 minutes. That taught me the value of taking breaks.

What kept me going was seeing small wins. When the conflict detection finally worked correctly, I was ecstatic. When the API responded in under a second, I felt like I'd achieved something huge. The testing phase was intense - I wrote over 200 test cases, and each one taught me something new about edge cases I hadn't considered. It was tedious work, but it made the final product so much better. Looking back, TALA taught me that persistence pays off. Not every day was productive, but every day I learned something. The project isn't perfect, but it's mine, and I'm proud of what I built.

post4.title: Understanding Machine Learning: My Journey from Zero to Building Models
post4.excerpt: Machine learning seemed like magic when I first heard about it. How could a computer learn? It didn't make sense to me at first...
post4.content:
Machine learning seemed like magic when I first heard about it. How could a computer learn? It didn't make sense to me at first. I remember watching a YouTube video about neural networks and thinking 'this is way too complicated for me.' But something about it intrigued me, so I kept watching more videos, reading articles, and trying to wrap my head around the concepts. It took me a solid month before things started clicking, and even then, I felt like I was just scratching the surface.

I started with the basics - understanding what machine learning actually is. It's not magic, it's math and statistics applied in clever ways. Once I understood that, everything started to click. My first model was terrible - it could barely predict anything correctly, and I was honestly embarrassed to show it to anyone. But that's okay - everyone's first model is bad. What matters is that I kept improving it. I spent countless hours tweaking parameters, trying different algorithms, and learning from my mistakes. I learned about linear regression, decision trees, neural networks - each one has its place, and understanding when to use which is crucial.

The breakthrough came when I built my first model that actually worked well. It was a simple sentiment analysis model, but seeing it correctly classify text felt amazing. That moment when I ran a test and got 85% accuracy - I literally jumped out of my chair. That's when I knew I wanted to dive deeper. Now, I work with ML models regularly in my projects. The field is constantly evolving, and there's always something new to learn. My advice? Start simple, build projects, and don't be afraid to fail. Every mistake is a learning opportunity, and trust me, you'll make plenty of them.

post5.title: Working in a Team: Lessons from the IEMELIF Church Website Project
post5.excerpt: Before this project, I mostly worked alone. But building a website for a church required a team, and that taught me so much about collaboration...
post5.content:
Before this project, I mostly worked alone. I was used to coding by myself, making all the decisions, and not having to explain my choices to anyone. But building a website for a church required a team, and that taught me so much about collaboration. We were a team of four, each with different strengths. One person was great at design, another at backend, I focused on testing and integration. At first, it was chaotic - everyone had different ideas about how things should work, and we spent way too much time in meetings just trying to agree on basic things like color schemes and button placements.

Communication was key. We started having daily stand-ups, even if they were just 15 minutes. It helped us stay aligned and catch issues early. I learned that over-communicating is better than under-communicating. Git conflicts were a nightmare at first - we all worked on different features, but sometimes we'd step on each other's code. I remember one time when three of us were working on the same file and we ended up with merge conflicts that took us an entire afternoon to resolve. That's when I really learned about branching strategies and code reviews. Now I always create a new branch for every feature, no matter how small.

The most valuable lesson? Trust your teammates. I used to want to check everything myself, but I learned to trust that others knew what they were doing. That doesn't mean being careless - it means giving people space to do their best work. By the end, we delivered the project ahead of schedule, and the client was really happy with the result. Working in a team is challenging, but the results are so much better when you combine different perspectives and skills. Plus, it's way more fun than working alone.

post6.title: Building the FEU Tech AI Chatbot: From Idea to Production
post6.excerpt: The FEU chatbot project was my first real experience with production AI systems. It was exciting, stressful, and incredibly educational...
post6.content:
The FEU chatbot project was my first real experience with production AI systems. It was exciting, stressful, and incredibly educational. When we started, the chatbot was slow - response times were around 2.5 seconds, which felt like forever. Students would ask a question and wait, and sometimes they'd ask again thinking it didn't work. I remember getting feedback from users saying the chatbot felt 'broken' because it took too long to respond. That really motivated me to fix the performance issues.

Optimizing the response time became my mission. I spent days profiling the code, finding bottlenecks, and testing different approaches. I tried caching, database optimization, and even rewriting some parts of the code. The breakthrough came when I optimized the semantic search - that alone cut the time in half. Working with GPT-4 was fascinating. The API is powerful, but you need to structure your prompts carefully. I learned that small changes in how you phrase things can make huge differences in the output quality. I must have rewritten the prompt engineering logic at least 20 times before I was happy with it.

Testing was crucial. I created hundreds of test cases covering different question types, edge cases, and error scenarios. Some bugs only appeared under specific conditions, and finding those was like detective work. The day we hit 99.9% uptime was a huge milestone - I actually celebrated with my team. Keeping a system running reliably is harder than building it in the first place. Monitoring, logging, and having good error handling are essential. This project taught me that building AI systems isn't just about the model - it's about the entire system working together smoothly. And honestly, that's the fun part.

post7.title: Why I Love Testing: Finding Bugs Before Users Do
post7.excerpt: Most developers hate testing, but I actually enjoy it. There's something satisfying about finding a bug and fixing it before it causes problems...
post7.content:
Most developers hate testing, but I actually enjoy it. There's something satisfying about finding a bug and fixing it before it causes problems. I know, I know - that makes me sound weird. But hear me out. I didn't always feel this way. When I first started, testing felt like a chore - something you had to do but didn't want to. I'd write my code, run it once to see if it worked, and then move on. That was my testing process, and I thought it was enough. But then I saw what happens when you don't test properly.

During one project, I pushed code without thorough testing. A few days later, users started reporting issues. I had to rush to fix it, and it was stressful. I spent an entire weekend debugging and fixing bugs that I could have caught earlier. That experience changed my perspective completely. Now, I write tests as I code. It's become part of my workflow. When I write a function, I immediately think about how to test it. What edge cases should I consider? What could go wrong? I've gotten so used to it that I feel weird when I don't write tests.

Automated testing is a game-changer. Setting up CI/CD pipelines means tests run automatically, catching issues before they reach production. It's like having a safety net that's always there. I've found bugs that would have been embarrassing if users had seen them - like a function that would crash if you passed it an empty string, or a calculation that was off by one in certain edge cases. That feeling of catching something before it causes problems is addictive. Testing isn't just about finding bugs - it's about building confidence in your code. My advice to other developers: don't skip testing. It might seem like extra work, but it saves so much time and stress in the long run. Plus, well-tested code is easier to refactor and maintain.

post8.title: From Customer Service to Coding: How My Past Experience Helps Me Now
post8.excerpt: People sometimes ask why I worked in customer service when I wanted to be a developer. The truth is, those two years taught me skills I use every day...
post8.content:
People sometimes ask why I worked in customer service when I wanted to be a developer. The truth is, those two years taught me skills I use every day. At first, I thought it was just a job to pay the bills while I was studying, but looking back, it was one of the best learning experiences I've had. Customer service taught me patience in a way that nothing else could. When you're dealing with frustrated people who are yelling at you over the phone, you learn to stay calm and think clearly. That same patience helps me when debugging complex code or dealing with difficult bugs that just won't go away. I've had bugs that took me days to fix, and my customer service experience taught me not to give up.

Communication skills are crucial in tech, and I learned that the hard way in customer service. Explaining technical concepts to non-technical people, writing clear documentation, collaborating with team members - all of this is easier because of my customer service background. I also learned about compliance and following procedures. In customer service, you have to follow HIPAA and financial regulations strictly - one mistake could cost the company thousands of dollars. That attention to detail and understanding of compliance translates directly to writing secure code and following best practices. I'm always thinking about security and data protection because of that experience.

Problem-solving under pressure was another skill I developed. When a customer has an urgent issue, you can't just walk away. You have to find a solution, and fast. That mindset helps me when I'm facing tight deadlines or critical bugs. Most importantly, customer service taught me to think from the user's perspective. When I'm building features now, I always ask: 'Would a user understand this? Is this intuitive?' That perspective makes me a better developer. Every experience teaches you something. Don't discount any job or experience - you never know what skills will be useful later.

post9.title: Building the AI Skill Assessment Platform: What I Learned About User Experience
post9.excerpt: Building an assessment platform taught me that good code isn't enough - you need to think about how people will actually use your product...
post9.content:
Building an assessment platform taught me that good code isn't enough - you need to think about how people will actually use your product. At first, I focused on the technical side - making sure the scoring algorithm was accurate, the database was efficient, all that. I was proud of my code, and I thought the interface looked fine. But when we tested it with real users, we discovered issues I never considered. Watching people struggle with something I thought was intuitive was a real wake-up call.

Users found the interface confusing. Questions appeared in a way that felt overwhelming - I had put all the questions on one page because I thought it would be faster. But users told us it was stressful and hard to focus. The feedback wasn't clear either - I had technical error messages that made sense to me but confused everyone else. I realized I had been thinking like a developer, not like a user. We redesigned the user flow based on feedback. We made questions appear one at a time, added progress indicators, and improved the feedback system. The difference was night and day - users actually enjoyed taking the assessment after we made those changes.

I learned that user testing is essential. What makes sense to you as a developer might not make sense to your users. Getting real people to use your product early and often is crucial. Accessibility was another thing I learned about - making sure the platform works for everyone, regardless of their technical skill level, is important. Simple things like clear instructions and helpful error messages make a huge difference. Now, whenever I build something, I think about the user experience from the start. Good UX isn't something you add at the end - it's something you design from the beginning. And honestly, it makes the whole development process more enjoyable.

post10.title: Data Analysis: Turning Numbers into Insights
post10.excerpt: Working with data at FEU taught me that data analysis is more than just crunching numbers - it's about finding stories in the data...
post10.content:
Working with data at FEU taught me that data analysis is more than just crunching numbers - it's about finding stories in the data. When I first started, I thought data analysis was just running queries and making charts. I'd write a SQL query, get some numbers, put them in a chart, and call it done. But I quickly learned it's much more than that. You need to understand what the data means, what questions to ask, and how to present findings in a way that makes sense to people who aren't data analysts. That's the hard part.

Cleaning data is 80% of the work, and nobody tells you that when you're learning. Real-world data is messy - missing values, duplicates, inconsistencies, typos, you name it. I remember spending an entire week just cleaning one dataset before I could even start analyzing it. Learning to clean data properly is a skill in itself, and it's crucial for getting accurate results. One time, I found that a simple typo in the data (someone wrote 'Male' as 'Mael') was causing my analysis to be completely wrong. That taught me to always double-check my data cleaning process.

Visualization is key. A well-designed chart can communicate insights instantly, while a poorly designed one can confuse people. I spent time learning about data visualization best practices, and it made a huge difference in how my work was received. One project involved analyzing student performance data. By looking at patterns, I identified factors that correlated with success. These insights helped the institution make data-driven decisions about resource allocation. The most satisfying part is when you find something unexpected - a pattern that no one noticed before, or a correlation that explains a problem. That's when data analysis feels like detective work. Data analysis taught me to be skeptical and verify everything. Just because two things correlate doesn't mean one causes the other. Critical thinking is essential.

post11.title: Learning React: From Confusion to Confidence
post11.excerpt: React was intimidating at first. Components, props, state, hooks - it all seemed so complicated. But once I got the hang of it, it became my favorite framework...
post11.content:
React was intimidating at first. Components, props, state, hooks - it all seemed so complicated. I remember looking at my first React code and thinking 'what is all this JSX stuff?' It looked like HTML but it wasn't, and that confused me. But once I got the hang of it, it became my favorite framework. I started with the official React tutorial, and honestly, I was lost. The concepts didn't click immediately. I kept asking myself: 'Why do I need all this complexity? Can't I just use plain JavaScript?' But I stuck with it, and I'm glad I did.

What helped was building something simple. I created a basic todo app, and that's when things started making sense. Seeing how components work together, how state flows through the app, how props pass data - it all clicked. I spent hours just playing around with different ways to structure components, and each experiment taught me something new. Hooks were a game-changer. useState and useEffect became my best friends. Learning when to use which hook took practice - I remember using useEffect for everything at first, which was definitely wrong. But once I understood the patterns, React became much more intuitive.

Building this portfolio website was a great learning experience. I got to practice everything - component structure, state management, animations, and more. Every feature I added taught me something new. The React community is amazing. There are so many resources, libraries, and helpful people. Whenever I got stuck, I could find answers on Stack Overflow or ask for help in Discord communities. That support makes learning React much easier. My advice for learning React: start small, build projects, and don't try to learn everything at once. Focus on the fundamentals first - components, props, and state. Once those make sense, everything else builds on that foundation.

post12.title: Deploying My First Project: Lessons Learned the Hard Way
post12.excerpt: Getting code to work on my computer is one thing. Getting it to work on a server where other people can access it? That's a whole different challenge...
post12.content:
Getting code to work on my computer is one thing. Getting it to work on a server where other people can access it? That's a whole different challenge. My first deployment attempt was a disaster. I thought I could just upload my files and it would work - how hard could it be? Nope. Environment variables, dependencies, server configuration - there were so many things I didn't consider. I spent an entire weekend trying to get my app to run on a server, and I was ready to give up multiple times.

The first issue was dependencies. My local environment had packages installed that weren't in the requirements file. The server couldn't find them, and the app crashed immediately. I had no idea what was wrong until someone told me to check the server logs. Lesson learned: always use virtual environments and keep requirements files updated. Environment variables were another headache. I had hardcoded some values in my code (bad practice, I know), and they didn't work on the server. Learning to use environment variables properly was a crucial lesson. I had to rewrite parts of my code just to make it work in production.

Database connections were tricky too. Local databases work differently than production databases. I had to learn about connection pooling, timeouts, and proper error handling. The most frustrating part was debugging production issues. When something breaks locally, you can use print statements and debuggers. In production, you need proper logging and monitoring tools. I remember spending hours trying to figure out why my app was crashing, only to realize it was a simple database connection timeout. Now, I always test deployments in a staging environment first. I use proper logging, error handling, and monitoring. Deployment isn't just about pushing code - it's about making sure everything works in the real world. My advice: learn about deployment early. Don't wait until you need to deploy something important. Practice with small projects, and you'll avoid a lot of headaches later.

post13.title: The Importance of Documentation: Why I Write Everything Down
post13.excerpt: I used to think documentation was a waste of time. Why write about code when you could just write more code? I was wrong...
post13.content:
I used to think documentation was a waste of time. Why write about code when you could just write more code? I was wrong, and I learned that the hard way. There was a project I worked on six months ago. When I came back to it recently, I had no idea how it worked. The code made sense - I could read it and understand what each function did - but I couldn't remember why I made certain decisions or how the different parts connected. I spent hours trying to figure out my own code, which was frustrating and embarrassing.

That's when I realized the value of good documentation. Not just comments in code, but actual documentation - README files, architecture notes, API documentation. Good documentation saves time. When someone new joins a project, they can get up to speed faster. When you come back to old code, you understand it immediately. When something breaks, you know where to look. I also learned that documentation helps you think. When you have to explain something in writing, you often discover gaps in your understanding. Writing documentation forces you to really understand what you built. I've caught so many bugs just by trying to document how something works.

Now, I document as I go. When I add a feature, I update the documentation. When I fix a bug, I note what the issue was and how I fixed it. It's become part of my workflow, and I actually enjoy it now. Documentation doesn't have to be perfect. It just has to be helpful. Even simple notes are better than nothing. I keep a simple markdown file for each project where I jot down important decisions, gotchas, and things I learned. Start documenting your projects, and you'll thank yourself later. Trust me on this one.

post14.title: Organizing CS Expo 2024: Leadership Lessons Outside of Coding
post14.excerpt: Organizing a tech event taught me skills I never expected to learn. It wasn't about coding at all, but it made me a better developer...
post14.content:
Organizing a tech event taught me skills I never expected to learn. It wasn't about coding at all, but it made me a better developer. Planning CS Expo 2024 was like managing a complex project with many moving parts. Speakers, sponsors, venue, schedule, marketing - everything had to come together. It was overwhelming at first. I remember the first planning meeting where we listed all the things we needed to do, and the list was so long that I thought we'd never finish in time. But we did, and it taught me a lot about project management.

I learned about project management without realizing it. Breaking down big tasks into smaller ones, setting deadlines, coordinating with different people - these are all skills that apply to software development too. Communication was crucial. I had to talk to professors, students, sponsors, and vendors. Each group had different needs and concerns, and I had to learn how to communicate with each one effectively. Learning to communicate effectively with different stakeholders is valuable in any career. I also learned that sometimes you have to be firm but polite, especially when dealing with vendors who weren't delivering on time.

Problem-solving under pressure was another lesson. Things go wrong in events - speakers cancel, equipment fails, schedules change. I remember one speaker canceled the day before the event, and we had to find a replacement in less than 24 hours. Learning to stay calm and find solutions quickly is a skill I use in my development work too. The event was successful, and seeing everything come together was incredibly satisfying. But more than that, I learned that being a developer isn't just about writing code - it's about solving problems, working with people, and making things happen. Leadership isn't about being in charge - it's about helping a team achieve a common goal. That mindset has made me a better team member and collaborator in all my projects.

post15.title: My Learning Philosophy: Why I Never Stop Studying
post15.excerpt: Technology changes fast. What's relevant today might be outdated tomorrow. That's why I made a commitment to never stop learning...
post15.content:
Technology changes fast. What's relevant today might be outdated tomorrow. That's why I made a commitment to never stop learning. I don't wait for someone to teach me something. If I need to learn a new technology for a project, I dive in. Online courses, documentation, tutorials, practice projects - I use whatever works. I've learned so many things just by reading documentation and trying things out. Sometimes I'll spend hours on something that should take 10 minutes, but that's how I learn best - by doing.

But learning isn't just about consuming information. It's about applying it. I always build something with what I learn. That's how knowledge sticks. Reading about React is one thing - building a project with it is another. I also learn from mistakes. Every bug I fix, every error I encounter, teaches me something. I keep notes about problems I've solved and solutions I've found. That knowledge base grows over time, and I refer back to it constantly. I have a folder full of notes about different technologies, common errors, and solutions that have saved me hours of debugging.

Teaching others is part of my learning process too. When I explain something to someone else, I understand it better myself. That's why I write blog posts, help classmates, and share what I know. The tech field is exciting because there's always something new. AI, new frameworks, better tools - staying curious and open to learning keeps me engaged and motivated. My philosophy is simple: learn something new every day, even if it's small. Over time, those small learnings add up to significant growth. Never stop being a student, even when you become a teacher. And honestly, that's what keeps this field interesting - there's always more to discover.
